summary.p: A copy of the grammar of the High Tamil (centamiḻ) composed in Latin by the Italian Jesuit Giuseppe Costantino Beschi (1680-1740).
By a Christian copyist as indicated by the cross in the header of each page.

support.p: Same watermark as found in manuscripts BnF Indien 189, 190, 617, and 634 (see Colas and Colas-Chauhan 1995: 51, 67). The watermark shows the letter T surmounted by a crown and placed on a base, itself surmounting a cartouche which contains a J followed by a fleur-de-lis and the name CUSSON (cf. nos. 3292 and 3293, pl. 424 and no. 694, pl. 109 in Heawood 1969 [1950]).

desc.p: According to Filliozat (1937: 283, fn. 1) this is a copy made by Abraham-Hyacinthe Anquetil-Duperron (1731-1805) (see BnF NAF 22436 for an example of his handwriting). However, the handwriting in this manuscript seems to be similar to that of Jean Calmette (1692-1739 or 1740). As he declares in a letter sent from Ballabaram in 1732, he was among those Jesuits who copied some of the manuscripts sent to the Royal Library (fonds Brotier 89, fol. 37a, 37b cited in Colas and Chauhan 1995: 11).
The puḷḷi is marked only on cinna ra and is otherwise not regularly used.
Double-curled kompu is not used. The differentiation between o/ō, e/ē is marked by a stroke placed above the letter in order to mark the short C.
Differentiation between ra/ā is marked by a stroke placed above it. The periya ra is has a double loop.

Stamps are found at the beginning of the manuscript, on p. 1, and at the end, on p. 81. The stamp used is a red circle with a double line containing 3 fleurs-de-lis surmounted by a crown with the inscription BIBLIOTHEQUE ROYALE. This stamp is a variant of the stamp n. 21 in Josserand and Bruno (1960: 281), in use during the Bourbon Restoration (July 1830 - January 1831).

p.p: The cover boards at the front and back of the book appear to be attached to the quires by the cords which are secured by means of channeling.

The boards and spine are covered with paper which is folded over the edges of the boards forming a turn-ins and glued down. Pastedowns of an initial and a final bifolios onto the inside of the board partially conceal these mechanism of the binding and also the channeling. The manuscript is made of 33 quires of six or three bifolios.

origin.origDate:
No internal date. The terminus ad quem is 1739, the date of the Catalogus in which this manuscript is described.
1760 in Vinson (1867: 49 and 1867-1868: 46) and in Vinson and Feer (1866-: 46). Indeed, in Cabaton (1912: 32) the same date has been corrected with an annotation in 1739.
If this manuscript was copied by Calmette the date woould be pushed further back up to 1730, even though the manuscript is not listed among those sent by the Jesuits to the Royal Library in the 1730's (see Omont 1902; Colas 1997).
